A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as any other. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving out questions.

Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada for 10 years or more by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer:

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer diet
- Pioneer schools
- Pioneer churches
- Pioneer transportation and social life
- Pioneer farming experiences
- Folklore in Saskatchewan
- Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaires to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER EXPERIENCES A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure that name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: RICHARD P. STEPHENSON

2. Your address: 854 AVENUE ST. REGIS, SASKATOON

3. Date: AUGUST 1935

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): WILLIAM YAKIMA, ENGLAND

5. What was your father's name and occupation?: RICHARD STEPHENSON, QUALIFIED VETERINARIAN

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): NOVEMBER, 1904

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:

   DELORAIN, MANITOBA

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or if you may use "I was a small child" or "I was in my teens", etc):

9. What were your reasons for coming to Canada?

   AVENUE OF OPPORTUNITIES

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?):

    THROUGH A COMPANY WORKING ON A FARM AT DELORAIN, MANITOBA GOVERNMENT INFORMATION.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Not really in favor, by applying ones self opportunity was at home fairly good.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

Along with a friend from town of residence.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Same by old Allan Liner "Kenangton" about 15 days crossing.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

A charge assortment of immigrants very sociable having, seasick most of trip was tempted to go overboard, great depth of snow at train was held up at Crystal City several hours till snowplow cleared.

Winnipeg was desperately cold after leaving Liverpool I well remember at an open bare on cart on deck while in the Irish sea a sudden gust took my hat into ocean.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Davidson, Assiniboia at that date on prairie 9 miles east.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Davidson.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Saskatoon, Rosetown

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

After leaving school at 15 in York, Yorkshire was in an auctioneer & commission agents office for 5 years.

First 7 months at DeHoraine & worked out for a farmer learning Canadian methods at $15 per month.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   Quite regularly. To several, received replies equally as good. You see a nice girl as one to attract attention but never got back to Canada.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
   I was teaching for 3 years when friend became interested. April 29, 1908, married Elizabeth May Goff at Davidson.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation as a place to settle?
   I was instrumental in the following coming out from England: Frank Gordon, Beat Bull, Dunn & Horace Williams, Robert Potter.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.
   One sister came out to Prince Albert to join her husband in 1912, both returning eventually to England 2-3 years later.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
   The earliest years visited neighbors regularly by buggy or sleigh some wonderful times & plenty local talent, mostly good. A dozen miles was the handicap, for services on Sunday had a good attendance via a neighbor's house, ultimately transferred to school when built during summer months we had a regular student, later when cars were in use, we went in for evening services in town.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
   The usual trips into village for supplies & visited similar sized places like Imperial, Sampson at first time no No. 2 Highway all cross-country travel & drove several times with team to Mandal (now Watrous) by road & very lonesome trip. At that time blizzards & snow was very bitter cold. Experienced long trips for firewood 25 miles returning home by chance almost exhausted. The spring of 1906 depression & railways closed always held up for 3 weeks to relieve situation & pieces 8x8 bridge timber raised by Mayor of Davidson written in each other's forget.
25. When was the first car used in the community? I cannot say definitely.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   Not till 1916. Model A Ford new.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Davidson. 9 miles.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   Yes, this town was very progressive & went ahead rapidly. Many U.S.A. settlers were brought in by Mr. Brown, and he also farmed. At this time horses were usual way of travel.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   About once a week, mail was main attraction. Remember in 1905 travelling on a cart 18 miles one day.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   Would say roughly around 1920.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   Not before 1910. Then mostly clothing, really buying values as family increased. A little later on purchased even more for larger quantities of groceries through a wholesale firm at that date, Mr. Bros.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   Possibly 1920 or thereabouts. Can't be sure.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   Intended to try it for 3 years but after taking up land in Assiniboia Nov. 1904, decided to remain, & really liking it. Next year was always a drawing card.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1927? What reasons did they have for moving?

The everybody seemed satisfied new settlers were still coming and not until the dry period set in that moved a few away north many U.S.A. buyers of land at high prices just pulled out.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

The number would be large enough but mostly U.S.A. settlers who never understood.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Please give the name and address of other pioneers who could answer this question.

If someone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person give name and address here:

_________________________
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:
Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

Would you or the person who owns them either
(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying? .......
(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon? ....... (indicate your preference, if any) ..................

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

Our family consists of 4 sons & daughters all living within a total of 23 grandchildren.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

Methods of marketing, farming machinery, roads, hospitals, travelling conveniences, dial telephone, radio & television, shopping centres, protection of homes, shorter work hours, stated holidays, family allowances, old age pension, unemployment insurance.
